Water is lazy (well, all systems with energy are). It will try to get some rest. When you push down the ping pong ball you do disturb the water's normally balanced state. It will therefore receive some potential energy (while rising) that it will use to try to stabilize itself to go back to its restful state. The ping pong ball is way to heavy to push when you are holding onto it, and the walls of the glass are also too robust. The only direction that the water may go is downward, and the force downwards will therefore be equal to the weight of the displaced water (plus the neglected weight of the ping pong ball). For the acrylic ball the situation is almost exactly the same. The scale will push the water upwards with the a force equal to the buoyant force. That force is less than the weight of the acrylic ball and the lazy water will therefore push downwards with all the energy it got, i.e. the buoyant force. The ball can't help to push at all since it's completely prevented from doing that by the string. So, the consequence is that the system remains balanced. However, in the first experiment where the ping pong ball was attached to the bottom of the cup, the water couldn't push on the scale. It will push on the bottom of the glass, but the glass will remain in rest because of the upward buoyant force from the string. So, consequently,  there's no force on the left side of the scale while there's a force equal to the buoyant force on  the right side of the scale.

Force on left side of balance:

Here's how I like to look at (both) experiments.  Forget about the balls themselves, and concentrate on the net force that's actually exerted on the bottom of the beakers.  In a way, other forces "don't matter," because they're not actually touching the bottom.

Water pressure is a function of the water's depth.  So, since the water depth was the same for both beakers (in both experiments), the pressure at the bottom was also the same.  And that means (since the beakers are identical and have the same surface area at the bottom), the FORCE exerted downward by the water, on the bottom of the beaker, is the same.  Let's call that amount of force "F_wp" (force due to water pressure).

In experiment #1, the left-side beaker has a force F_wp pushing down on the beaker's bottom, and a tension force T pulling up on the beaker's bottom.  The net downward force on the beaker's bottom is F_wp - T.

Meanwhile, the right-side beaker has a net downward force of F_wp acting on it.  This more that F_wp - T, so that side descends.

In experiment #2, each beaker's bottom has a downward force of F_wp acting on it.  So the beakers balance.

The best way to describe this result is to imagine that there is no liquid. Imagine both beakers empty and that you are conducting this experiment with environmental air. Since the liquids are the same in each beaker, the density of it is moot. Therefore it can be as dense as metal or as light as air. Imaging both beakers with balls hovering in them obviously would be balanced as they contribute no mass to the scale. The same theory can be applied to the original experiment. The way I think about this problem is ignoring the balls and focusing on the force on the beakers (as it’s the beakers that contact the scales, not the balls).
The water creates pressure on the sides of the beaker and on its base. The lateral pressure on the sides is equal around the circumference of the beaker in all directions, with a net resultant of zero, and therefore may be ignored. The pressure on the base of the beaker is proportional to the depth of water above it, which – multiplied by the area of the base – gives a force downward on the beaker, and thus downward on the scales.
In experiment 1 both beakers have equal depth of water, so equal downward force due to water pressure alone. The reason the ping-pong beaker rose was because this beaker had an additional force upward from the tension of the ball due to buoyancy, which partially offset the downward force due to water pressure.
In experiment 2, there is no such tension on the beaker base – both beaker bases have only (equal) downward water pressure. The act of pushing the ping-pong ball downward simply displaced water, increasing the effective depth, which increases the pressure on the base (thus the force), until it equaled that of the beaker with the suspended ball.
I find this way of thinking about it easier, though perhaps less instructive as (with the exception of acknowledging the ball buoyancy causing tension in the tether in the first experiment) it dodges the question of what forces are acting on the balls themselves.

My better way of explaining it would simply involve equal and opposite forces.  The ball on the right is pulling down on the string with the same force that the string is pulling up on the ball.  Therefore, the weight of the ball becomes irrelevant, and the only variable that effects the result is the amount of water displaced.  On the left, the force of the ball pushing upward is equal to the force of the fingers pushing down.  Because it is buoyant, the ball's weight only reduces the upward force it exerts and thus the downward force of the fingers.  Therefore, the balls weight is compensated for by a reduction of the total force necessary to keep it submerged, and the only relevant variable is the amount of water displaced.  Since the amount of water displaced on both sides is equal, the scale is balanced.  Even though the counter forces on each side are working in opposite directions (one pulling up and the other pushing down), they are essentially doing the same job, countering the exertion of force by the ball with a counter force outside of the beaker and insuring that only the displacement of the water effects the experiment.

The way it works best in my head (although I perfectly understand the way you explain it, which is the more technically correct way of explaining it) is the following:

Scenario 1: (ball tethered to beaker)
When the ball is tethered to the beaker, it forms part of the beaker/balance system. Thus, since there is a buoyant force pulling upwards, this effectively reduces the overall weight of that specific beaker (going downward; Fu - Fd = Ftotal, assuming upwards is the positive direction). On the other beaker, the ball does not form part of the beaker/balance system, since it is tethered to an external ground, thus the buoyancy force does not pull the beaker up with it, but a reaction force to the buoyant force pushes the beaker down, thus making it heavier.

Scenario 2: (untethered ball to beaker)
When you push the ball downward, you are effectively doing the same thing that the other ball is doing: you removed the only way through which the buoyant force could possibly reduce the overall weight of that beaker, and introduced a reaction force (your finger) to the buoyant force, which is added to the overall weight of that beaker. Since both balls are (approximately) the same volume and displace the same amount of water... voila, you got two balanced beakers.
